metadata.key_specifications: 32-Kb EEPROM Serial I2C devices, 4096 words of 8 bits each, 32-byte page write buffer, support Standard (100 kHz), Fast (400 kHz) and Fast-Plus (1 MHz) I2C protocol, 1,000,000 program/erase cycles endurance, 100 years data retention
metadata.applications: The datasheet does not explicitly mention main applications, but based on the device description, it can be used in embedded systems, IoT devices, and other applications requiring non-volatile memory and I2C communication.

page_summaries.content: The CAT24C32BC4 and CAT24C32BAC4 are EEPROM Serial 32−Kb I2C devices available in a 4 −ball WLCSP package. Both devices are internally organized as 4096 words of 8 bits each. They feature a 32−byte page write buffer and support the Standard (100 kHz), Fast (400 kHz) and Fast−Plus (1 MHz) I2C protocol.

Table 2. RELIABILITY CHARACTERISTICS (Note 2)
Symbol Parameter Min Units
NEND (Note 3) Endurance 1,000,000 Program/Erase Cycles
TDR Data Retention 100 Years

Table 5. A.C. CHARACTERISTICS (VCC = 1.7 V to 5.5 V, TA = −40C to +85C) (Note 5)
Symbol Parameter Standard Fast Fast−Plus Units
Min Max Min Max Min Max
FSCL Clock Frequency 100 400 1,000 kHz
tHD:STA START Condition Hold Time 4 0.6 0.25 /C0109s
tLOW Low Period of SCL Clock 4.7 1.3 0.45 /C0109s
tHIGH High Period of SCL Clock 4 0.6 0.35 /C0109s

The CAT24C32BC4/CAT24C32BAC4 supports the Inter-Integrated Circuit (I2C) Bus protocol. The protocol relies on the use of a Master device, which provides the clock and directs bus traffic, and Slave devices which execute requests. The CAT24C32BC4/CAT24C32BAC4 operates as a Slave device. Both Master and Slave can transmit or receive, but only the Master can assign those roles.

Byte Write
To write data to memory, the Master creates a START condition on the bus and then broadcasts a Slave address with the R/W bit set to '0'. The Master then sends two address bytes and a data byte and concludes the session by creating a STOP condition on the bus. The Slave responds with ACK after every byte sent by the Master (Figure 6). The STOP starts the internal Write cycle, and while this operation is in progress (tWR), the SDA output is tri-stated and the Slave does not acknowledge the Master (Figure 7).

Page Write
The Byte Write operation can be expanded to Page Write, by sending more than one data byte to the Slave before issuing the STOP condition (Figure 8). Up to 32 distinct data bytes can be loaded into the internal Page Write Buffer starting at the address provided by the Master. The page address is latched, and as long as the Master keeps sending data, the internal byte address is incremented up to the end of page, where it then wraps around (within the page). New data can therefore replace data loaded earlier. Following the STOP, data loaded during the Page Write session will be written to memory in a single internal Write cycle (tWR).

Acknowledge Polling
As soon (and as long) as internal Write is in progress, the Slave will not acknowledge the Master. This feature enables the Master to immediately follow-up with a new Read or Write request, rather than wait for the maximum specified Write time (tWR) to elapse. Upon receiving a NoACK response from the Slave, the Master simply repeats the request until the Slave responds with ACK.

Delivery State
The CAT24C32BC4/CAT24C32BAC4 is shipped erased, i.e., all bytes are FFh.

To read data from memory, the Master creates a START condition on the bus and then broadcasts a Slave address with the R/W bit set to '1'. The Slave responds with ACK and starts shifting out data residing at the current address. After receiving the data, the Master responds with NoACK and terminates the session by creating a STOP condition on the bus (Figure 9). The Slave then returns to Standby mode.

Product Summary.content: The CAT24C32BC4 and CAT24C32BAC4 are EEPROM Serial 32-Kb I2C devices available in a 4-ball WLCSP package. They are internally organized as 4096 words of 8 bits each and feature a 32-byte page write buffer.
The CAT24C32BC4 and CAT24C32BAC4 support the Standard (100 kHz), Fast (400 kHz) and Fast-Plus (1 MHz) I2C protocol.
CAT24C32BC4CTR B WLCSP-4 with Die Coat I = Industrial (-40C to +85C) SnAg Tape & Reel, 5,000 Units / Reel.
CAT24C32BAC4CTR (Note 9) J WLCSP-4 with Die Coat I = Industrial (-40C to +85C) SnAg Tape & Reel, 5,000 Units / Reel.

Electrical Characteristics.content: Table 2 provides reliability characteristics, including endurance (minimum 1,000,000 program/erase cycles) and data retention (minimum 100 years).

Table 5 lists A.C. characteristics such as clock frequency, timing for START condition hold, low period of SCL clock, and high period of SCL clock. The values are provided for different speed grades: Standard, Fast, and Fast-Plus.

To read data from memory, the Master initiates a START condition, sends a Slave address with the R/W bit set to '1', and the Slave responds with ACK. The Slave then starts shifting out data at the current address. After receiving data, the Master responds with NoACK and creates a STOP condition to terminate the session, returning the Slave to Standby mode.

Reliability and Environmental Conditions.content: Table 2 provides reliability characteristics for the electronic component, including endurance (NEND) and data retention (TDR) specifications. The endurance is rated for a minimum of 1,000,000 program/erase cycles, ensuring long-lasting performance under repeated write and erase operations.

The data retention characteristic specifies a minimum of 100 years, indicating the component's ability to reliably store data for an extended period without loss or corruption. These reliability parameters are crucial for applications that require robust and durable data storage.

The table presents key reliability characteristics related to endurance and data retention, which are essential for assessing the component's suitability for various operating conditions and environmental factors. Reliable data storage and endurance under repeated write/erase cycles are critical considerations in electronic component selection.

Reliability characteristics such as endurance and data retention are vital specifications that define the component's performance and longevity under different usage scenarios. These parameters provide insights into the component's ability to withstand repeated programming and erasure cycles while ensuring data integrity over an extended period.
